subject: Quikscript Practice
msgSnippet: Everyone, Scott has set up a site where discussion about QS or Shavian can take place plus easy practice reading and typing in QS.
messageBody:
Everyone,
 
Scott has set up a site where discussion about QS or Shavian can take place plus easy practice reading and typing in QS.  http://www.cookeys.net/~shavian/cgi-bin/ikonboard.cgi  I would suggest following my last post on (I believe) March 29 and get Keyman on your computer.  Typing in QS with this mapping is about a zillion times easier than using the mapping Jerome was originally set for, which is in line with the Shavian mapping.  Additionally, the new mapping permits use of all the half-letters and ligature letters, alternative "n" and schwa symbols.  These, of course, can be ignored if one is still working in junior QS, but they are there ready to be used when you are ready to move on to senior QS.  Despite what some in the Shavian group have said, I feel the additions Read made to QS after extensive testing make it a beautiful script that, even in a computer font, shows its flexibility and artistry.  I would like to see more QS fonts developed.  Any potential font-makers in our group?
 
I believe there is nothing like reading other people's QS to improve your own reading fluency.  And, if you haven't tried it, start taking a few notes during your day in QS.  When you get good at it, it is almost as efficient as shorthand.
 
Thanks again to Ewout Stam for helping me get it through my head that Keyman would work with the existing Jerome font.
 
Paige Gabhart
